formalText: Tanya and he went to wedding of one of her cousins this weekend, which was a hard time for him.
Normal kind of annoyances that go along with going anywhere with her family.
No one's ever on time for anything.
So it's sort of like the failure to match one's own expectations is a particularly frustrating part for him anyways.
There were particular vows that were especially hard to hear.

that's the part that contains the forsaking all others piece.

of his marriage was a really good time for longer than a few weeks.

He made that and he was fully aware of Tanya's history of depression and anxiety.
That was her sort of default state during the wedding planning.
So it's hard to deal with when it feels vaguely like a bait and switch. Like there'll be both of these things.
It's not been a whole lot of good things.
Tanya's father and her sister both came to visit them in Andover, but he hasn't really seen or really spoken with either of them in five or six months.
They've been in touch with Tanya talking to her, which is good.
But they've essentially not been communicating with him at all.
It's sort of like, things have been hard here.
He's wondering where they have all been, and they're not going to even talk about it having been hard or anything the entire time that they're there.
And so he feels more alone in this and angry about that.
Not that they're particularly people that he would rely on.

He is deeply unhappy and deeply angry about his situation.
He's sitting here trying to sort out why he is so unhappy and angry about this.
And it seems like the more he tries to recapture the sense of self, the more he's like, what the hell was all of this.
The claim of lack of control seems like a convenient excuse or something
on her part.

There's one piece of dealing with Tanya's illness in the present and then also in the past, which is sort of a traumatic event that he went through that he feels completely alone in, and he can't share with her because she was there and not there at the same time.
It's not even about her illness.
He's not exactly sure how to have those conversations.

they're at a whole lot of pent-up frustration, and on the other hand,
it's not particularly clear that she can handle a conversation where he's very frustrated.

He just doesn't have a particularly clear view of what a tenable strategy is at this point.
He's thinking that in order to express it to her,
he has to find the right level of not caring about the impact on her.

he wants to smash everything.

He thinks that in her case, she feels like she ought to do something, but isn't quite clear what it is, and that she has set up some sort of guilt cycle that prevents her from speaking to him except when she's really drunk.
